original_title: Sri Lanka’s central bank recommends import relaxation sans vehicles
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s central bank has recommended to relaxation of import controls of 900 items except motor vehicles, Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe said.
“The decision on how to relax, when to relax, phasing out is a decision of the Finance Minister,” Governor Weerasinghe told reporters on July 06 after cutting policy rates.
Thereafter about 300 items will remain under import controls, made up of motor vehicles and some other items, he said.
Under an International Monetary fund program, June targets have been except for revenues because import duties were much lower than expected.
“That is why we have recommended to the government to relax the import restriction so that we can collect some revenues as well,” Governor Weerasinghe said.
Sri Lanka controlled the imports of over 3000 items in 2020 after the deployment of macro-economic policy in the form of rate cuts on top of tax cuts blew a hole in the balance of payments.
In Sri Lanka imports are controlled after money printing (rate cuts or central bank refinance) trigger forex shortages, further worsening tax collections. (16/07/2023)
